text: Does anyone have advice about how to remotely collaborate on a single Pluto notebook?

elements.text: Does anyone have advice about how to remotely collaborate on a single Pluto notebook?

text: if you can both ssh into the same machine, it should "just work"?

elements.text: if you can both ssh into the same machine, it should "just work"?
That... would be brillant

text: actually I have a feeling there would be some port-forwarding related issue now that I think more about it

text: The true pain was actually to forward the port through the ssh jump I need to perform to access my office workstation.

elements.text: You can use

text: I have done this with Fons. It’s great

elements.text: I have done this with Fons. It’s great

text: +1 for ngrok! It does expose your localhost to anyone who visits the (random) generated url, so if security is a concern you can do `ngrok http -auth="username:password" 1234` to protect the page with some credentials (you do need to have a (free) ngrok account to set this up). You could even include the credentials in the ngrok link like this: `<https://username>:password@<ngrok numbers>.<http://ngrok.io|ngrok.io>` so it automatically logs in (ofc you should only send this link to people you trust)

elements.text: +1 for ngrok! It does expose your localhost to anyone who visits the (random) generated url, so if security is a concern you can do
ngrok http -auth="username:password" 1234
to protect the page with some credentials (you do need to have a (free) ngrok account to set this up). You could even include the credentials in the ngrok link like this:
:password@<ngrok numbers>.
ngrok.io
so it automatically logs in (ofc you should only send this link to people you trust)

text: You have to be careful though with things like Sliders. They update on one client but not the other.
